page.title: 16PUBLIC HOUSES
page.content: The{Coal House}is a public house built in 1760 by the riverside in Apperley. When the{River Severn}is flooded the Coal House can be surrounded by up to eight feet of water. The furniture is still very old fashioned because the owners who also own a guttering firm prefer it that way. The landlady is German and the Landlord is Irish. Originally the'White Lion' it was renamed because it's jetty was used to land coal for sale in the area. The {Yew Tree at Chaceley Stock,}originally a cider house, was always a boatee's pub. It was extended c 1700. Old customers remember that, before the weir was built at Maisemore,{Severn {Trows}were stranded on the mud at low tide. A Stock is a 'wharf' and the pub was probably situated at a river crossing point at low tide. The publican is a native of Staffordshire.
